title: (x) NBC Olympic Typeface - modified Insignia/Bonn {Stephen L}
content:
Searched all over for this one and can't seem to find an answer. This one is on the tip of my tongue, but I just can't figure it out!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100224082426im_/http:/typophile.com/files/nbc_5285.png)
author: kdeval31

comments.content: Hi Kevin. Looks to me like a customised [Insignia](http://web.archive.org/web/20100224082426/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/insignia/?testdrive=dock%3Dfalse%26size%3D71%26w%3D600%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3DALPINE%2520SKIING%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3Dot.liga%26seed%3D22) by Neville Brody.
Yes, and to rephrase Stephen – [Insignia without the extended crossbars could be Bonn.](http://web.archive.org/web/20100224082426/http:/www.typophile.com/node/61021)
Interesting, Florian. I haven't run into Bonn before. So, you think this could be Bonn? Or just Insignia modified to look like Bonn?

Yes, I think this could be Bonn. The typeface was originally designed for the [KAH Bonn](http://web.archive.org/web/20100224082426/http:/www.kah-bonn.de/index.htm), but has also been employed by Neville Brody for his redesign of the ORF identity (Austrian Broadcasting Corporation). Unfortunately, I haven’t been able to track down a full specimen of Bonn. Maybe Paul Stonier can help?
Oh, so you think it may have been an exclusive at one point, but no more? If it is the apparently obscure Bonn I'd love to know how NBC (or whoever does their graphics) came to be using it?

By the way, visiting that link I was confirmed once again in my love of the German language.

KUNST UND AUSSTELLUNGSHALLE DER BUNDESREPUBLIK DEUTSCHLAND

Wow! English can't even come close to such grand expressiveness. Even if it wasn't in all-caps. :)

And nice to see they're holding an exhibition on James Cook travellin' down my way.
